Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: The store was buzzing with the end-of-day rush, and I was laser-focused on counting the register, making sure every bill and coin matched the receipts. As a cashier, I knew how important it was to get this right—one mistake, and the numbers wouldn’t add up, and I’d be held responsible. My hands moved quickly, but my mind kept drifting to the text from my mom: “Don’t forget, dinner starts at six. Grandma expects you to help with the prayers.” It was our family tradition, and missing it would disappoint everyone, especially Grandma, who always said I was the bridge between generations. I felt the weight of her expectations pressing on me, but the clock was ticking, and I still had a stack of receipts to reconcile. My heart pounded as I glanced at the time, torn between the duty to my family and the responsibility to my job. I could feel the stress building, knowing that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
